Grace Sherwood, Respondent, v. William H. Crane, Appellant. (New York Common Pleas

—General Term,

April, 1895.) In an action for breach of contract of employment as an actress, the plaintiff's testimony tended to show that she was employed to act in a certain play, and that defendant’s agent told her it would be a permanent thing for her until the close of the season, and assured her that defendant did not produce failures and that the play would run until June first, and agreed to pay her a specified sum per week until the close of the season. Held, that such testimony, if believed by the jury, warranted a finding that the contract was for the entire season and not merely.for the run of the play, and that it was not error for the court to so charge. Appeal from an affirmance by the City Court at General Term of a judgment in favor of plaintiff entered upon the verdict of a jury and of an order denying a motion for a new trial. Gibson Putzel, for appellant. Howe de Hummel, for respondent. Daly, Ch. J.

The plaintiff claims damages for breach of contract of employment by the defendant, a theatrical manager, under which she was to perform at the Star Theatre in a plav"called “Brother Jonathan,” the performances of which were to commence in the latter part of February, 1893, and to run until about June first, at a salary of sixty dollars per week. The defense is that she was not employed for any particular period, but only for the run of the play, which lasted hut six weeks, and that her employment was conditional upon her rehearsal of the part to the satisfaction of the author of the play and of the defendant. She was notified in February, during the rehearsals, that her services were not needed, and she remained out of employment thereafter for the whole term, except one week, in which she earned $50. The case was submitted to the jury, who found for the plaintiff in $910, being the whole amount claimed by her after deducting the $50 earned hy her.

Defendant concedes that there was a question of fact for *84the jury upon the evidence as to the terms of the contract, but claims error in the charge of the court as to what would constitute a contract for a definite period as distinguished from an engagement for the run of the play. The court said : “ I charge that if the jury believe the testimony of Miss Sherwood, namely, that Brooks told her that Crane, the defendant, made no mistakes and that the play would run until June 1st, that was the contract, and she is not limited to six weeks, but is entitled to recover for the full period.” To this the defendant excepted.

The defendant contends that the evidence shows that the plaintiff was engaged only for the run of the play, and that the statement of Brooks, the defendant’s agent, who engaged her, that the play would run to June first, was mere opinion and not a warranty that it would so continue. The testimony of plaintiff on her direct examination was that Brooks said : “This means a permanent thing for you in Rew York from the opening until the balance of the season. I will give you $60 a week from the time we open until the balance of the season; ” that she said, “ Suppose the play is a failure ? ” he said, “ Crane does not produce failures ; ” she said, “ How long is the season ? ” he said, “We will open in three or four weeks, at the very latest, from January 30th, and it will extend to about June 1st.” On cross-examination she was asked: “ Q. I call your attention particularly to the conversation you had with Brooks the first time you met him, and I ask you the question whether or not it was not a fact that Brooks said to you you were engaged for the run of the play? A. Yes. Q. That is it ? A. Yes, and I asked him how long the run would be, and he'told me about three.weeks from January 30th until or about June 1st. Q. And that he told you would be the run of the play ? A. Yes.” And, again: “ A. My first conversation with him I was engaged from the time I say until on or about June 1st. Q. For the run of the play? A. Yes; that is the length of the run of the play. Q. And he told you in his opinion it would run to June 1st about ? A. Yes.”

*85From this testimony, if the jury believe it, there was no doubt that Brooks not only expressed an opinion that the play would run until June first, but had so much confidence in Mr. Crane’s judgment of plays and ability to run them as long as he pleased that he was willing to and did contract with plaintiff that her engagement in this piece would last to that date; so that, while he engaged the plaintiff for the run of the play, he distinctly specified that run as extending to June first, and there was no error in the instruction of the court on that point.

But if there were a doubt as to the sense in which Brooks’ statement as to the run of the piece and plaintiff’s engagement are to be understood, defendant is not entitled to the benefit of that doubt, for it is manifest that, from Brooks’ declaration to plaintiff, that “ this means a permanent thing for you in Mew York from the opening until the balance of the season,” and ÍCI will give you $60 a week from the time we open until the balance of the season,” together with his other statements, that he must have supposed that the plaintiff understood he was contracting for the season; and this understanding constitutes the contract. “ Where the language of a promisor may be understood in more senses than one, it is to be interpreted in the sense in which he had reason to suppose it was understood by the promisee.” Hoffman v. Etna F. Ins. Co., 32 N. Y. 405, citing Potter v. Ontario Ins. Co., 5 Hill, 149; Barlow v. Scott, 24 N. Y. 40. It is to be observed that defendant did not ask that any question with regard to plaintiff’s understanding, or what defendant supposed, or had reason to suppose that understanding to be, should be submitted to the jury, but contented himself with an exception to the instruction quoted.

The judgment should be affirmed, with costs.

Bischoff and Pbyob, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed, with costs.
